# English Test Sentences for Nasty Parsing
#
# This file contains standard test sentences organized by complexity and
# grammatical structures. Used for regression testing of the parsing pipeline.
#
# Format: Each non-comment, non-empty line is a separate test sentence.

## Simple Sentences (Subject-Verb-Object)

The cat sat.
The dog runs.
Birds fly.
She eats.
John sleeps.

## Transitive Sentences (with Direct Object)

The cat ate the food.
John reads books.
Mary loves music.
The dog chased the ball.
Children play games.

## Sentences with Modifiers

The big cat sat.
The quick brown fox jumped.
A very happy child laughed.
The extremely fast runner won.
Several small birds flew away.

## Prepositional Phrases

The cat sat on the mat.
The book is on the table.
John walked to the store.
Mary lives in New York.
The bird flew over the house.

## Complex Noun Phrases

The big black cat sat.
The old wooden table broke.
A beautiful red rose bloomed.
The three little pigs ran.
My best friend arrived.

## Verb Phrases with Auxiliaries

The cat is running.
John has eaten.
Mary will go.
The dog was barking.
Children have been playing.

## Sentences with Multiple Complements

John gave Mary the book.
The teacher told students a story.
Mary showed her friend the picture.
Dad bought me a toy.
She sent him a message.

## Coordination

John and Mary walked.
The cat ate and slept.
Birds fly and sing.
She laughed or cried.
He walked but didn't run.

## Subordinate Clauses

John left because he was tired.
Mary smiled when she saw him.
The cat slept while I worked.
If it rains, we stay inside.
Although tired, she continued working.

## Relative Clauses

The cat that sits is happy.
The book that John read was good.
The man who called left.
The place where we met was nice.
The day when she arrived was sunny.

## Passive Voice

The food was eaten by the cat.
The book was read by John.
The ball was chased by the dog.
The story was told by the teacher.
The house was built by workers.

## Questions

Who ate the food?
What did John read?
Where is Mary?
When will she arrive?
How did he do it?
Why did they leave?

## Imperatives

Sit down.
Read the book.
Come here.
Don't go.
Please wait.

## Complex Sentences

The cat that was sleeping on the mat woke up when the dog barked.
John, who works at Google, lives in San Francisco.
Although Mary was tired, she finished the project that was due.
The book on the table is the one that John read yesterday.
When the sun rises, the birds start singing in the trees.

## Copular Sentences

The cat is happy.
John is a teacher.
Mary is in the house.
The food smells good.
He seems tired.

## Sentences with Particles

John picked up the book.
Mary turned off the light.
The cat looked out the window.
He gave up trying.
She put down her bag.

## Multi-clause Coordination

John walked to the store and Mary went to the park.
The cat slept on the couch but the dog played outside.
She studied hard yet she failed the test.
He cooked dinner so she cleaned the dishes.

## Negation

The cat did not eat.
John doesn't like coffee.
Mary isn't here.
They won't come.
I haven't seen him.

## Reflexives and Reciprocals

John hurt himself.
Mary prepared herself.
They helped each other.
We know ourselves.
The children taught themselves.

## Comparative and Superlative

John is taller than Mary.
The cat is faster than the dog.
This is the best book.
She is the smartest student.
That was the worst day.

## Quantifiers

Every cat sat.
Some dogs ran.
All birds fly.
Many children played.
Few people came.
No one left.

## Time Expressions

John arrived yesterday.
Mary will leave tomorrow.
The cat slept all day.
Birds fly south in winter.
We meet every Monday.

## Complex Coordination with Ellipsis

John reads books and Mary magazines.
The cat is black and the dog white.
She can sing and he dance.

## Long Distance Dependencies

What did John say Mary bought?
Who does she think left?
The book that I think John said Mary read was interesting.
